creatorScripts.title: Anti-Polyester / Toxin Angle
creatorScripts.hook: Guy holding up two shirts, looking at labels
creatorScripts.script:
So I was doing laundry the other day and I actually looked at the tag on one of my shirts.

95% polyester.

I didn't really think about it before. It's just‚Ä¶ what shirts are made of, right?

But then I started reading about microplastics. Like, how they found them in human brains now. In testes. In semen.

And I'm like‚Ä¶ wait. Where do microplastics come from?

Turns out? Polyester. Every time you wash it, every time you sweat in it, it's shedding tiny plastic particles. Directly onto your skin.

I looked at my whole closet. Almost everything was polyester.

That's when I found UndrDog. 51% hemp, 31% bamboo, 18% organic cotton. Zero polyester. Zero microplastics.

I didn't even know you could make a tee that tough without plastic.

[Shows shirt, maybe tugs it]

Now I don't even think about it. I just know what I'm wearing isn't adding to the problem.

creatorScripts.title: Durability Focus
creatorScripts.hook: Holding tee + something destructive (knife, lighter, etc.)
creatorScripts.script:
Every few months I'd notice another hole. Another stretched-out collar. Another shirt that just‚Ä¶ gave up.

And I'd just buy another one. That was the cycle.

At some point I did the math. I was spending like $200 a year on shirts that lasted maybe 6 months.

Then someone told me about hemp. How it's actually the strongest natural fiber. Like, farmers used to make rope out of it.

So I tried UndrDog.

[Does durability demo ‚Äî pull, tug, whatever fits]

I've had this one for almost a year now. Washed it probably 50 times. Still looks like week one.

They have this lifetime guarantee thing. I haven't needed it. But it's nice knowing it's there.

I stopped buying tees. I just have these now.

creatorScripts.title: Airflow / Breathability Focus
creatorScripts.hook: Outside in the heat, or post-workout
creatorScripts.script:
I sweat. Like, a lot. Always have.

Every tee I owned would get those pit stains. That stuck-to-your-back feeling. And the smell‚Ä¶ man.

I tried all the "moisture-wicking" stuff. Performance fabrics. Didn't really help. Just felt like wearing a plastic bag that dried faster.

Then I learned about bamboo. The actual plant has these micro-gaps in the fiber that let air flow through.

UndrDog uses 31% bamboo in their blend. First time I wore one on a hot day, I noticed it immediately.

[Maybe fans shirt out]

It breathes. Like, actually breathes. I don't get that suffocating feeling anymore.

And because it's natural fiber ‚Äî not plastic ‚Äî it doesn't trap odor the same way.

I can wear this all day and not feel like I need to change by 3pm.

creatorScripts.title: Health / Microplastics Focus
creatorScripts.script:
I was down a rabbit hole the other night. You know how it goes.

Started reading about microplastics. How they're finding them everywhere now. Water. Food. Air.

But then I saw this study ‚Äî they found microplastics in human testes. And another one found them in semen.

And the researchers are like‚Ä¶ we don't know where it's all coming from yet. But one source is synthetic clothing. Polyester.

I looked at what I was wearing. 100% polyester.

[Pauses]

I have a two year old. Me and my wife are thinking about another kid.

I don't know if my shirt is the problem. But I know it's not helping.

So I switched to UndrDog. Hemp, bamboo, organic cotton. No plastic.

Maybe it's overkill. Maybe it doesn't matter.

But I'd rather not find out the hard way, you know?

creatorScripts.title: The Conspiracy Angle
creatorScripts.hook: Standing in closet looking at clothes
creatorScripts.script:
Here's something that doesn't make sense to me.

Hemp has been around for thousands of years. They wrote the Declaration of Independence on hemp paper. George Washington grew it.

Then in the 1930s, it got banned. Right when DuPont was patenting synthetic fibers. Right when the plastics industry was taking off.

Coincidence? I don't know.

But for almost a century, we've been wearing plastic shirts while hemp ‚Äî the strongest, most breathable natural fiber on the planet ‚Äî was illegal to grow.

That changed in 2018. Hemp's legal again.

And now there's this company making tees out of it. 51% hemp. No polyester. Lifetime guarantee.

[Shows shirt]

This is what shirts were supposed to be before the plastic industry got involved.

I'm not saying it's a conspiracy. I'm just saying‚Ä¶ it makes you think.

creatorScripts.title: The Microwave Test
creatorScripts.script:
So I've been seeing all this stuff about microplastics in your body.

And I started wondering‚Ä¶ what even IS my shirt made of?

Most tees are polyester. Polyester is plastic. Plastic comes from petroleum.

So I did a little experiment.

[Puts polyester shirt on plate, puts in microwave]

[Shows result ‚Äî melted, deformed, maybe smoking]

That's what's touching your skin all day.

[Holds up UndrDog tee]

This one's hemp, bamboo, and organic cotton. Let's see what happens.

[Microwaves it ‚Äî nothing happens]

Plants don't melt.

Your shirt shouldn't either.
creatorScripts.concept: Visual proof that polyester is literally plastic. Polyester melts/deforms, hemp doesn't. Scroll-stopping 'wait, what?' moment.

creatorScripts.title: The Laundry Water Filter Test
creatorScripts.script: Coming soon ‚Äî filter the water from washing polyester vs hemp tee. Show the microplastic particles.
creatorScripts.concept: Tangible visual of invisible problem. 'See what you've been breathing/absorbing.' Scientific feel without being preachy. Easy to replicate, hard to fake.
